}} 'Ernest Arthur Randell' (25 January 1873 â 12 May 1938) was an Australian
public servant and cricketer who played three matches for Western Australia. The
son of George Randell, who was a member of the Legislative Council, and Mary
Louise Smith (his father's second wife), Randell was born in Perth, where he was
raised. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/41686074 "The
Late Mr. E. A. Randell"] â [[The West Australian]]. Published 2 December
2012. After his mother's death in August 1874, his father remarried to
Lucy James (nÃ©e Francisco), who had been widowed the previous year. Randell thus
became the step-brother of Walter James, ten years his elder, who would later
become Premier of Western Australia.

Playing for Perth in WACA grade cricket, Randell led the competition's batting
aggregates during the 1890â91 season. He was
selected to tour the eastern colonies with a state team in early
1893. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/26224251/2572284 "INTERSTATE
MATCHES: PAST VISITING TEAMS"] â [[The West Australian]]. Published 27 March
1909. Randell played in both first-class matches on tour (against South
Australia and Victoria), [http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/16/16591/First-
Class_Matches.html First-Class Matches played by Ernest Randell (3)] â
CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2012. opening the batting with
William Back in the second
match. [http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/3/3917.html Victoria v
Western Australia], Other First-Class matches in Australia 1892/93 â
CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2012. His only further first-class
match came when South Australia toured the colony at the end of the 1898â99
season. Batting at number ten in both innings, Randell scored 36 runs in Western
Australia's second innings, his highest first-class
score. [http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/5/5141.html Western
Australia v South Australia], Other First-Class matches in Australia 1898/99 â
CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2012. He continued to play against
touring sides into his thirties. [http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players-
/16/16591/Miscellaneous_Matches.html Miscellaneous Matches played by Ernest
Randell (5)] â CricketArchive. Retrieved 2 December 2012.

Having worked in both the Education and Treasury Departments, Randell later
worked with Leslie and Co., and was a resident of Gunyidi for a period of time.
Following his father into the Congregationalist movement, he was heavily
involved with the Trinity Congregational Church in Perth, serving as a church
officer as well as superintendent of the church's Sunday school. Randell died at
the Mount Hospital in Perth in May 1938, and was buried in the Congregational
section of Karrakatta Cemetery.
